results.title: Home of the blizzard (1913)
results.brief_description: Frank Hurley (1885-1962) was firmly established by 1925 as Australia’s most famous photographer. An artist interested less in expressing human experiences than the grandeur of nature and the romance of exotic lands, his work was known to Australians through books, newspaper features and documentary films.
results.description: Frank Hurley (1885-1962) was firmly established by 1925 as Australia’s most famous photographer. An artist interested less in expressing human experiences than the grandeur of nature and the romance of exotic lands, his work was known to Australians through books, newspaper features and documentary films. His journeys began in December, 1911 when he joined Mawson’s expedition to Antarctica as official photographer; his stills of the Expedition were widely published around the world and this documentary “Home of the Blizzard” was released in 1913.
description_for_label: Frank Hurley (1885-1962) was firmly established by 1925 as Australia’s most famous photographer. An artist interested less in expressing human experiences than the grandeur of nature and the romance of exotic lands, his work was known to Australians through books, newspaper features and documentary films. His journeys began in December, 1911 when he joined Mawson’s expedition to Antarctica as official photographer; his stills of the Expedition were widely published around the world and this documentary “Home of the Blizzard” was released in 1913.

results.title: Home made 35mm Film Projector
results.brief_description:
True example of Australian ingenuity - spool arms made from bicycle pedal shanks. But it worked, and was the main component of an early days home cinema.
1 of 2: Projector
2 of 2: Box of memorabilia (4 x Cinema tickets / 1 x ‘Operation newsreel’ sticker / 1 x ‘Hoyts’ badge / 1 x ‘Last Film Search’ badge / 1 x ‘On Our Selection’ postcard / 1 x Glass slide advertisement / 1 x ‘Pathe’ small 35mm can of something / 1 x empty 35mm 50’ can of ‘Fox Movietone News’ / 1 x ‘Kodak’ roll of photographic film / 1 x ‘Build your own projector’ book / 1 x ‘Material for Radio Electrical and Mechanical’ catalogue / 1 x ‘Sun News Pictorial Hobby Book’ / 1 x ‘Liberty Theatre’ advertisment mounted on cardboard)

results.title: Home help (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Stephen Segaller and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World in action”.
Brindle House in Cheshire treats people with acute psychiatric problems in an informal atmosphere, as out-patients. The staff believe that by being more accessible they are able to intervene before patients reach a critical stage. They also believe that the process of recovery is aided if the patient can remain within the community among family and friends.

results.title: Home front: 1939-1945
results.creator_credit: Annice Vass and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: Newsreels of Australia during World War II including diggers marching to the war, Prime Minister Curtin addressing the nation, the War Fund Parades, panic buying, the Japanese bombing of Darwin, the Land Army women and the civilian war effort. The final segments look at the Peace celebrations of 1945.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Annice Vass and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia

The final segments look at the Peace celebrations of 1945.

results.title: Home from the Hill
results.creator_credit: Molly Dineen and National Film and Television School (Great Britain)
results.brief_description: After forty years of service in India and Africa, Colonel Hilary Hook returns home to England. We follow his journey from his Kenyan home and servants to an England very different from the one he left in 1948. This is a documentary about a dying breed of colonials. Colonel Hook represents those who once thought it was their responsibility to civilise the world, or a good part of it, only to find the world changing too fast for them to keep up. The pride with which Hook was prepared to cope, and the occasional despair when things proved too difficult, make him an absorbing central character and a remarkable microcosm of the fading British Empire. Rated: G
results.creator_credit_for_label: Molly Dineen and National Film and Television School (Great Britain)

results.title: Home free
results.creator_credit: Fruits and Roots Production, Rebecca Yates and Glen Salzman
results.brief_description: Reverses the traditional story of the ethnic child assimilated into Western culture by placing a ten-year-old white girl into a new cultural environment - a Chinese neighbourhood. Conveys the mystery, threat and strangeness of the “new” community as experienced by the girl. Suitable for upper primary level.

results.title: Home country
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Julie Mongta-Saunders and ACMI
results.brief_description: Julie Mongta/Saunders traces the movement of her family over time, both geographically and generationally. Though scattered, this family have a strong connection, both to each other and the land of their birth, intensified by the sense of ‘coming home’.
